title: How to Make Sicilian Tomato Sauce

steps.headline: For authentic Siciliano-style, make sure you use fresh herbs whenever possible!
Mince two tablespoons of garlic (about four or five cloves).
steps.description: You may optionally use a garlic press or jarred minced garlic.

steps.headline: Pour the olive oil into the bottom of a four quart (or larger) saucepan and place over medium heat.
Add the diced onions into the pan once the oil is hot (usually one to two minutes).
steps.description: Cook for five to ten minutes, stirring occasionally, until onions are soft and translucent, but not brown.

steps.headline: Add the garlic into the pan and stir to mix with the onions.
steps.description: If you are using the raisins and pine nuts, this is the time to add them as well. Toast them GENTLY golden brown, they burn very easily!

steps.headline: Open all of your cans except for the tomato paste while the garlic is cooking, stirring after each can is opened.
steps.description: Chop the zucchini into bite-sized chunks.

steps.headline: Add the diced tomatoes into the pan and stir, allowing the mixture to come to a boil.
Add the crushed tomatoes and plain tomato sauce into the pan and stir, allowing the mixture to come to a boil again.
Open both top and bottom of both cans of tomato paste.
steps.description: Remove the top lids, and push the bottom lids through the cans to add the paste to the pan. Be sure to remove the bottom lids before they fall into your sauce!

steps.headline: Stir well to mix the tomato paste into your sauce.
steps.description: If the paste made your sauce too thick, add a cup of water.

steps.headline: Crush the anchovies and add them to the sauce; oil and all.
steps.description: [This is the real secret of a proper Siciliani-style sauce's body and flavor!!!]

steps.headline: Add the basil, oregano, parsley, and the salt; stir well.
Reduce heat and simmer for at least two hours, stirring occasionally.
Serve over pasta or use in your favorite Italian dishes.
steps.description: Top with grated mozzarella or Pecorino Siciliano cheeses!

text: For authentic Siciliano-style, make sure you use fresh herbs whenever possible! its really worth it! Dice one large vidalia onion.  Mince two tablespoons of garlic (about four or five cloves). You may optionally use a garlic press or jarred minced garlic. Pour the olive oil into the bottom of a four quart (or larger) saucepan and place over medium heat.  Add the diced onions into the pan once the oil is hot (usually one to two minutes). Cook for five to ten minutes, stirring occasionally, until onions are soft and translucent, but not brown. Add the garlic into the pan and stir to mix with the onions. If you are using the raisins and pine nuts, this is the time to add them as well. Toast them GENTLY golden brown, they burn very easily! Open all of your cans except for the tomato paste while the garlic is cooking, stirring after each can is opened. Chop the zucchini into bite-sized chunks. Add the diced tomatoes into the pan and stir, allowing the mixture to come to a boil. Add zucchini. Add the crushed tomatoes and plain tomato sauce into the pan and stir, allowing the mixture to come to a boil again.  Open both top and bottom of both cans of tomato paste. Remove the top lids, and push the bottom lids through the cans to add the paste to the pan. Be sure to remove the bottom lids before they fall into your sauce! Stir well to mix the tomato paste into your sauce. If the paste made your sauce too thick, add a cup of water. Crush the anchovies and add them to the sauce; oil and all. [This is the real secret of a proper Siciliani-style sauce's body and flavor!!!] Add the basil, oregano, parsley, and the salt; stir well.  Reduce heat and simmer for at least two hours, stirring occasionally.  Serve over pasta or use in your favorite Italian dishes. Top with grated mozzarella or Pecorino Siciliano cheeses!
